decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.	Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development shall conform in all material aspects with the plans and details shown in the application as listed below, unless variations are agreed by the Local Planning Authority in order to discharge other conditions attached to this decision:203/AE/01203/PL/01203/PL/02203/PL/03203/OS/01Reason:  For avoidance of doubt and in the interests of proper planning.

Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.	Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the side elevation walls of the building hereby approved without the prior written consent of the	Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking and/or re-enacting that Order) the proposed side elevation windows upon the first floor shall be non-opening and glazed with obscure glass to a specification to be agreed with the Local Planning Authority and shall be permanently maintained thereafter as non-opening and obscure glazed.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining premises from overlooking and	loss of privacy.

The roof area of the extension hereby permitted shall not be used as a balcony, roof garden or similar amenity area without the grant of further specific planning permission from the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining premises.

The Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:-carry out work to an existing party wall;-build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;-in some circumstances, carry out groundwork's within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:Appropriate works to reduce and maintain at appropriate size for location.Recommendation:Approve.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:As evidenced in the photos the tree is dead and becoming unsafe with a large cavity at the base and playing host to more than one fungi.Recommendation:Approve with the requirement to plant a replacement.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:All works necessary for health and safety as clearly seen in the photos with T.2 dead, T.3 snapped at base and hung up in adjacent trees and T.1 with a severe and increasing lean toward house and torsional fracturing in lower stem.Recommendation:Approve with condition for 3 replacements to be planted.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:Sufficient technical evidence including level monitoring has been provided to demonstrate that subsidence is still occuring and to implicate T.8. The Council should therefore permit the removal of the tree as there are no alternative management solutions in this instance which could be implemented to prevent further damage from occurring.Recommendation:Approve.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:As evidenced by the submitted documents and a further conversation with the Agent confirming key points, the trees are both in decline and are becoming dangerous. Removals are therefore for reasons of health and safety.Recommendation:Approve and require replacement via condition.
